question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: GRP (glass reinforced plastic)
why: Composites • Incredible strength (not lightweight though) Can be moulded into a range of complex 3D shapes and forms

correct_answers: Urea Formaldehyde
why: Polymers - Thermosetting • Very heat and electricity resistant - Handles extreme temeperatures

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Teak

correct_answers: Thermosetting, so not recyclable.
Kitchen work tops

Very brittle and cracks easily. Not good for structural purposes

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Expensive
Natural oils protect from insect and fungal attack outdoors. Strong, dense, hard.
why: Answer: Teak (Natural Timbers)

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: PMMA (Acrylic/perspex)
why: Polymers - Thermoforming • Brilliant optical properties (nearly 100% transparent). Rigid and hard. Easly formed with heat

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Can rust when exposed to air/water. Needs painting or other protection from elements. Heavy compared to Aluminium
Structures that require strength first - bridges, cars, bicycle frames, tools, machinery.
why: Answer: Steel (Metals / Alloys)

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Good balance of strength, hardness, bending resistance, fatique resistance a good 'does it all' plastic. Recyclable (technically)
Difficult to 3D print with (which is why we use PLA at school)

correct_answers: Thermosetting, so not recyclable - hard to mould
Saucepan handles. Plug sockets

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Boats hulls, fair ground rides, mould making, any custom
Costly manufacturing as very labour intensive. Less expensive than Carbon fibre. Not recyclable
why: Answer: GRP (glass reinforced plastic) (Composites)

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Carbonfibre
why: Composites • Incredible strength to weight ratio allowing very lightweight and strong parts - Can be moulded into a range of complex 3D shapes and forms

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Excellent fatigue resistance (bending back and forth) - Chemically resistant and easy to clean (not much sticks to it)
Difficult to glue to other materials as resists adhesives so well - Can only be bolted/riveted on.
why: Answer: Polypropylene (Polymers - Thermoforming)

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: TPU
why: Polymers - Thermoforming • Highly flexible and elastic - Stretchy and deformable

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Pine
why: Natural Timbers • Strong and lightweight for a timber - Easier to move. Easy to cut, join and work with. Takes a stain and can be coloured. Cheaper than oak where cost is important but gives effect of natural wood.

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Lightweight for it's strength, though not as strong as steel. Not as able to bend and deform as steel, tends to crack rather than flex.
Lightweight - Corrosion resistant outdoors, High tensile strength for it's weight. Easily extruded into tubes / rods
why: Answer: Aluminium (Metals / Alloys)

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Melamime Formaldehyde
why: Polymers - Thermosetting • Very hard and scratch resistant. Chemically resistant

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Oak
why: Natural Timbers • Very strong, dense, long lasting, hard and resistant to scratches and dents. Better outdoors than pine

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Uniform strength in all directions due to alternating grains
Not as cosmetically pretty as natural timber, as 'layers' can be seen on the edges
why: Answer: Plywood (Man Made timbers:)

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Aluminium

question: What material is shown?

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Stainless Steel

correct_answers: Not good for structural parts

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Does not corrode in even the harshest environments. Hard and scratch resistant. Antimicrobial, doesn’t rust and easy to clean.
Kitchenware, kitchen work tops, fittings on boats or for metal parts constantly exposed to outdoor weather.

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Steel
why: Metals / Alloys • High tensile strength. Hi compression and bending strength - Readily available. Easy to weld, join. Harder and more scratch resistant than aluminium

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: MDF and / or Chip board
why: Man Made timbers: • Very cheap as made from wood dust(scraps) and glue, dimensionally accurate

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Epoxy resin
why: Polymers - Thermosetting • Very strong bond. Used as adhesives. Sets with high transparancey. Often used with carbon fibre to make a composite.

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Terrible outdoors - Will soon rot away without suitable protection -
Strong and lightweight for a timber - Easier to move. Easy to cut, join and work with. Takes a stain and can be coloured. Cheaper than oak where cost is important but gives effect of natural wood.

question: What material is shown?
correct_answers: Brass
why: Metals / Alloys • An alloy of copper and Zinc - Great for decorative pieces. Self lubricating and low friction. Anti microbial.

question: Which statements apply to this material? (Select ALL that apply)
correct_answers: Cheap furniture panels - Often covered with a veneer layer of plastic or real wood to make it seem more expensive.
Not as cosmetically pretty as natural timber. Also has poor strength as no grain. Easily soaks up water and rots/deforms. Only for indoor use.
